comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: I concur. No water near Harrison NY. There was a train wreck at Harrison's Landing, CT in 1892, although the accounts I've read don't mention carriages landing in the water.

comment.author: 30225260@N02
comment._content: Whow!! very interesting documented, extraordinary picture indeed

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content:
Maybe it's this? 20 people died in this wreck. A definite cause was never found. Either the embankment gave way or the engine jumped the tracks. It took several days for divers to find all the bodies.

AFTER THE CRASH.; Efforts to Rescue the Passengers from the Cars in the Hudson River.

New York Times Oct 25, 1897. pg. 1

GARRISON'S, Oct. 24. -- After the moment of crash and splash, during which woodwork was torn, splintered, and ground into bits, and iron and steel were rent, twisted and broken, the waters closed silently and swiftly over the engine, the express car, and the combination car, while the first three sleeping cars, half submerged, were slowly sinking.

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Black and White [AllEdges], and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 77323348@N00
comment._content: Could be this one, but it's not Harrison NY or Connecticut. It's outside of Bridgeport Connecticut (I don't know if this is the same wreck but it could be): July 11, 1911 – outside of Bridgeport, Connecticut: The Federal Express, carrying the St. Louis Cardinals baseball team on a trip from Philadelphia to Boston, plunges down an 18-foot (5.5 m) embankment, killing 14 passengers.[7] No one from the team is killed. Got this info from Wikipedia here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_rail_accidents_(pre-1950) no mention of a wreck in Harrison NY or Connecticut.
